Pre-Lecture 5 Reading Before the lecture you should read: 6.5.4 Expected Value and Variance of the Uncorrected Sample Variance and the Sample Variance 6.6.1 Chi-Square Distribution 6.6.1.2 Sampling Distribution for Sample Variances When Sampling from Normal Populations NB: Not covering 6.6.1.1

Example 6-15 Using R, either via RStudio on your own device or this online console, answer these questions using an approximation from the Normal distribution and an exactly. # This code may be useful (you need to replace the _ with numerical expressions) 1 - pnorm(_, _, sqrt(_)) 1 - pbinom(_, _, _) pnorm(_, _, sqrt(_)) pbinom(_, _, _) Show the solution # Part a) approximation 1 - pnorm(0.11, 0.1, sqrt(0.1 * 0.9/500)) [1] 0.2280283 # OR 1 - pnorm(55, 500 * 0.1, sqrt(500 * 0.1 * 0.9)) [1] 0.2280283 # Part a) exact 1 - pbinom(54, 500, 0.1) [1] 0.2476933 # Part b) approximation pnorm(0.12, 0.1, sqrt(0.1 * 0.9/500)) [1] 0.9319814 #OR pnorm(60, 500 * 0.1, sqrt(500 * 0.1 * 0.9)) [1] 0.9319814 # Part b) exact pbinom(60, 500, 0.1) [1] 0.9381745 # See lecture slides or textbook for full solution

Example 6-16 Using R, either via RStudio on your own device or this online console, answer these questions using an approximation from the Normal distribution with a continuity correction and an exactly. # This code may be useful (you need to replace the _ with numerical expressions) sig <- sqrt((_ * _)/_) pnorm(_, _, sig) - pnorm(_, _, sig) pbinom(_, _, _) - pbinom(_, _, _) Show the solution # Approximately with continuity correction sig <- sqrt((0.383 * 0.617)/250) pnorm(0.402, 0.383, sig) - pnorm(0.358, 0.383, sig) [1] 0.5236417 # Exactly pbinom(100, 250, 0.383) - pbinom(89, 250, 0.383) [1] 0.5241166 # See lecture slides or textbook for full solution

Example 6-17 Use R, either via RStudio on your own device or this online console. Enter your answers in this Google form. # These functions may be useful (you need to replace the _ with numerical expressions) pchisq(_,_) qchisq(_,_) Show the solution # Part a) 1 - pchisq(126, 150) [1] 0.9233931 # Part b) pchisq(50, 65) - pchisq(40, 65) [1] 0.07861696 # Part c) pchisq(260, 220, lower = FALSE) [1] 0.03335803 # Part d) qchisq(0.6, 100) [1] 102.9459 # See lecture slides or textbook for full solutions

Example 6-20 Use R, either via RStudio on your own device or this online console. # These functions may be useful (you need to replace the _ with numerical expressions) pchisq(_,_) qchisq(_,_) Show the solution pchisq(15.98712, 10) - pchisq(4.865182, 10) [1] 0.7999983 # See lecture slides or textbook for full solution

Example 6-21 Use R, either via RStudio on your own device or this online console. # These functions may be useful (you need to replace the _ with numerical expressions) pchisq(_,_) qchisq(_,_) Show the solution pchisq(30 * (18.11898^2)/225, 30, lower = FALSE) [1] 0.0499998 # See lecture slides or textbook for full solution
